What is a good game? A question posed by the great scholars of not only our generation, but the generations that preceeded us. Up there with the likes of 'Why are we here', 'Is there a god' and 'Why do kids love Cinnamon Toast Crunch?'. Up until this day, this question has never been answered. Which is why I'm here.

A good game invokes emotion. A good game tells a story. A good game, is a good game.

ACE checks all but one of these boxes. ACE gets you to jump out of your seat, fist pumping in the air as you score that game-winning post goal. ACE gets you, head in hands, groaning at the incompotency of your goalie. ACE gets you to do all of this, and more. But what ACE doesn't do, is tell a story. What ACE does, is give the player, the oppurtunity to craft their OWN story. Their OWN legend. A game rich with replayability, a game rich with no glass ceiling, a game rich with a budding, growing e-sports scene. ACE let's you tell your own tale, your tale of bounce shots, your tale of overtime stress-fests, your tale of that one time where you scored a goal by bouncing the puck off their goalie. No other game does this, because no other game can. ACE acheives what very many dream of, but even more will never ever achieve.

Outside of the game, you find the company. The team behind, and pardon the rhyme, the dream. Spearhead Games. Responsible for such successes as Tiny Brains, as Stories. As ACE. With a community manager that cares, and a team of streamers dedicated to bringing you the best content they can at hitbox.tv/spearheadgames or twitch.tv/spearheadgames ACE is constantly changing. ACE isn't just a game. Spearhead Games isn't just a company. These two things, brought together, are a fire. A fire that we, the players. We, the viewers. We, the dreamers, stoke. Fuelling that desire to reach for the stars then bring them back. Flames licking at heros. Smoke billowing into the endless sky, the endless possibilites.

I can only tell you so much about ACE. I can only put into words, how great this game is, if you just give it a chance. It's up to you to decide if you like the game. But take it from someone whose not being to paid to say this, but will lose his job if he doesn't.

First off, forget all the hype and marketer-speak. Will Arena: Cyber Evolution be the next big e-sports craze? No, there's a 99% chance it won't. MOBA-like champion logic? What does that even mean?

Cyber Evolution is simply a 3 on 3 ice hockey game in space. That's it, although there really isn't anything wrong with that. What is wrong is that the controls are ponderously slow and floaty, and the puck is lost all too easily in the flashy graphical effects of special moves and players clashing at the goal. As for the community, it's currently extremely small. Prepare to play with and against a lot of bots. Despite Cyber Evolution's problems, I would recommend giving it a try. There is some fun to be had with it, and if its wrinkles are ironed out, it could become significantly more interesting. As it is now I'd give it a solid B-.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's like a chopped-down NHL game with comic-book cyber-fi competitors.  And it's awesome.

The game's simply a blast.  Rather, it's fun in its own simplicity.  You control one of three team mates (decently effective bots or players take the other slots), and a disc-puck-thing is dropped between you and the opposing team (where it is placed, precisely, is determined by last goal scored).  The teams rush for it, and use their unique players' abilities to snatch, slow, and stop the puck-handler.  Goals can be made by either dunking/running for a touchdown (run the puck into the net), or by shooting it in.  The grab-release mechanic allows for quick execution of shots, and easy interceptions.

This is still a very young game, so as long as the core components aren't messed with and there is some major (and I mean major, as far as the magically-laggy home screen is concerned) MAJOR performance issues addressed.  Personally I feel this game should run just fine for everyone, but for some reason it hates my (more than adequate) graphics card, and pretty much any time I'm not actually in a game (where there are zero server side or client side latency issues), the graphics seem to progressively drop the framerate.  It almost feels like their fog effects don't ever fully dissipate and just stack invisible particles, or something.

tl;dr Try it!  It's free, and it's fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really great. I don't know any other way to put it. You know you are having a great time when your heart is racing during the game, and afterwards you still can't stop shaking.

For anyone downloading the game for the first time, let me start by saying that as of right now, going in at a random time and clicking play to find 5 other people is very rare. It may be discouraging and feel like a dead game, but it is very much the opposite. Instead of deleting the game or never playing it because you can't find full games, watch the streams, go to the forums, and get help from a community member. Tournaments are almost daily, and pick-up games are very often. Finding a team is usually not too hard, and you can make it easy by inviting some friends to come play.

Essentially, the gameplay is just 3 on 3 hockey like matches, set in the future. There are a number of different runners designed to fill certain roles on a team, each with different speeds and abilities. Even though there is currently not a massive amount of runners, I am yet to get bored of the intense and exciting matches. There is no story/campaign mode, and the entire thing is a multiplayer game. If a player ques and finds no people or only a few (as happens often) then bots will fill in for the missing slots. Most players like to focus on a single runner to excel at, but once in the character selection nothing is holding you back from choosing any of the characters you have unlocked (all characters can be unlocked with in game currency, or real money, but please, do not get the impression that this is a pay to win game. Certain runners are stronger than others but every single one can be played well, and no runner is too far unbalanced.) The matches are a short 5 minutes long in an arena with each team trying to shoot the puck into the other teams goal.

The community for this game is awesome. Its very friendly, and alot of the members have almost the entire community on their friends list at this point. The community isn't very large at all, and alot of the players in it have been playing since the start, but you get to know everybody this way, making it really great despite the size

Honestly, this game has so many flaws currently, despite so many already being fixed. Lack of players, bad bot AI, bugs, balancing issues, and various other things all pull this game back. But i think it says something that even amidst all these problems that on other games would be enough to make me quit, this game has kept me coming back for more.

Seriously, check out this game, and remember, don't feel discouraged when at first you can't find anyone.

July 25, 2015
I guess I'm not the only one to have forgotten about this game. ACE really hasn't changed much since last year. The menus changed (for worse), there are some new characters and storyline stuff, and the tutorial is even less helpful, but the core game is unchanged. Network problems are undetectable, mostly because you will be placed in all bot matches within 60 seconds, and there is no one playing anymore. There's a bunch of skins and tournament stuff, but the game is pretty lifeless now.

Yes, the game is free, give it a shot if you are interested. Maybe you'll be one of the people that jumps in and gets hooked. I really don't expect most people to be like that. I found more players months ago, and I think server region splits really hurt. Even if you can find players, I don't feel the gameplay is satisfying enough. The arena feels huge and everything feels sluggish for a 5 minute match. Abilities will only be used a few times in a match, and it just doesn't feel fun. Those abilities are also still hard to land or identify, with particle overload making the game hard to understand as a viewer.

The developers work on growing a community, but I don't feel Early Access is being used to make the game more appealing. The old list of stretch goals has disappeared, and little issues remain. Updates have mostly been fixes and Ranked stuff, it seems like gameplay is not going to change. The tutorial uses a lot more words to teach less (it doesn't even teach passing now), and the menus are still unintuitive. Currency and progression systems are not explained clearly, and I still feel the power progression system is a mistake for a competitive game. There are only 2 supported resolution options listed, and graphics options are barren. Oh but they give away game currency and items, so usability issues disappear because free stuff. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have 20 hours in game, so I think I have a fair idea about it, and can write a decent review based on my time.

PROS

First game to utilize the MOBA style platform, but create an actual sport with it.

NOT P2W at all.  The items you buy, if you decide to buy them, are completely cosmetic.  Similar to LoL, there is no fee to play this game, and no downfall against people that have.  They just look cooler.

With a small community at the moment, it gives us the ability to really shape things, and get to know other players.  This can be both a Pro or a Con, depending on the personality types.

There is a decent amount of customizations you can do at this time already.  I am sure there will be lots more to come.


CONS

Bots.....  Yes, the bots.  This is quite possibly the most atrocious AI that I have ever come across.  I am sure this is just due to it being in alpha, but they are pretty much useless in any game.

Game has its share of lag, mainly because its under a P2P host atm.  The dedicated servers ARE coming, so this will likely lesson the lag considerably.

Exploiters are and will be around for the duration of the alpha, as with most alphas, until the bugs are submitted and fixes are made to stop this.  Just bear with it, time will fix this particular problem.


TL:DR

Overall, this is a fresh new take on a genre that was almost at its death.  They have reinvented a way for people to play competitively, and it is intense.  I find that the game is fast paced, very enjoyable (frustrating at the same time) and mostly, im excited for the future of this game.

Hope to see you in the arena.  Good luck and have fun.

Potential is an overused word in early access + alpha games and the story here is no different. Fortunately ACE is free-to-play and you don't have to worry about throwing away money at something that may end up in the dumps--only time. The idea behind ACE is simple and amazing. A sports game MOBA w/ a net and a.. ba.. puck... When I first started following ACE it was supposed to play more like a 3v3 futsal/soccer MOBA. Unfortunately the devs have strayed away from this and keep trying to mold it into some sort of hockey game. It is really sad to see how much of that has been stretched and forced into this game at this point. However, this game is still fun if you are content with the following:

Horrible lag (non-dedicated servers)
Leavers
Insanely stupid bots (that replace leavers)
Horrific in-game chat system
Glitchy gameplay
Collision detection worse than pong
One song (literally)

This is an alpha game and I am not really complaining, and that's why I gave it a recommend as I do, in fact, recommend this game. However, the reason to play this game is not for the gameplay (although it can be very fun at times). But rather the idea of this game. With A LOT of polish or perhaps another dev team can come along and create a new game based off of this idea, this can be a new genre that could easily break into the e-sports scene. Download it, play it. Let's see what these Canadian devs can do.

In a nutshell, this game is 3 on 3 hockey/soccer, with different archetypes/characters:

Enforcer/Goalie
Striker/Forward
Support/Midfield

At it's core, the simplicity of the game is why it is so much fun. It's very intuitive to control, and very rewarding when you are able to outmaneuver the opposing team(when they are putting up a good fight). That being said, there is a strange depth to the game- no match plays the same, and every day people are learning new things to play better and evolve the experience. Different team roles, different passing opportunities, juking, blocking, zoning.. I feel that this game has tremendous legs if it gets the chance to stretch them and run, and I would love to see it go far, as I would love to be able to keep playing it. The playerbase is still relatively small, but it is only growing. Please support the devs, play the game, and spread it around to your friends.

it's pre-alpha. there are bugs. occasionally a host will drop. sometimes you cant get in the game with your buddies. There are little things here and there, stuttery animations, lag spikes.. usual growing pains. The devs are being very open about what they are doing and what their priorities are- to be honest, even in the current state its more fun than I've recently had playing anything else.

The notion behind the game is great; with the success that mobas have had, it's only a matter of time before we see the rise of a mosa; a sports-like game that people can play in teams competetively. Unfortunately, there are a number of things that make me suspect this game will not be what the world will choose.

The mechanics of the game are simple, but the scale of the game itself, as well as the magnitude of that simplicity, hinder it. I just don't feel like there is enough variation possible in the gameplay, Sure, with 6 players on the field things can get intense for a few seconds at a time, but since it takes very little to deduce what works and what doesn't, there really isn't a whole lot going on at any given moment. It is arcade-y in its simplicity, and whilst that does make it easy to learn and easy to play, it ultimately limits the complexity of the end result.

The controls feel very sluggish; nothing close to the tight, precise, responsiveness you would want from a highly competetive game. There also seems to be a lot of pushing towards the microtransactions, which is understandable for a free game, but the way it is presented is not flattering.

For all the hype, this is merely 6-player ice hockey with a garishly stylised presentation.

Arena: Cyber Evolution
A game with great potential.


Visual: 7/10
The game has quite nice graphics, but is obviously low budget. The game has bright colours and an art-style that looks like most futuristic movies and games (meaning games with shiny futuristic objects, not to be confused with dystopian future.).


Sound: 7/10
The music in ACE is quite good, and is futuristic techno nonsense (which is not a bad thing.). Besides the music there is not alot of sound effects that get noticed. There is a crowd that cheers when you score a goal but that's just about it. There's not more to say really.

Gameplay: 7/10
The game has a hero system like League of Legends or Dota, but it's a futuristic sports game instead of being a 3-lane 5v5 game. Each character has two different abilities that can change the game drastically, such as the teleport ability or the ability to place a wall on the map. Besides the superpowers the game is basically a football game (I'm from Europe, so I guess it's soccer for the Americans reading this.). The game would've been rated higher if it weren't for the fact that it's basically dead.


Free To Play: 9/10
The game is entirely free to play, but you can purchase the heroes and skins for real money. This would normally be an issue for me but there are only 8 characters to play ( of which 4 are owned to begin with.).

I went into this one with no expectations and having no idea what the point of the game was at all. I think that made the experience better. That being said, it’s an early access game with definite room for improvement, but it gets a few things right. Let’s begin.

TLDR: Not Recommended

The Good

ACE – Arena: Cyber Evolution is like futuristic air hockey, only it’s played at a life-size scale. You can select from a few characters to play as (others you have to unlock through in-game currency). Each character has special abilities he or she can use to aid you and your team on the path to victory. I’m sure most of us (if not all of us) have played air hockey before. It’s fun and it’s a fairly acceptable way to kill some time. As the game stands now in it’s current state, that’s the highest praise I’ll be giving it. A dressed up game of air hockey.

The Bad

As I mentioned above, some characters need to be unlocked through in-game currency. The same holds for character customization options (skins and the like). Most of it you’d be forking over actual currency to get and that, to me, is an utter waste for a game like this.

The game has only two resolution settings, neither of which fit my monitor. Sad day.

The only other real complaint I had had to do with the controls. Well, one specific control. Holding down the left mouse button allows you to grab and hold onto the disc (puck). Releasing the left mouse button (in theory) allows you to shoot the disc in the direction your cursor is facing. 70% of the time when I tried to shoot the disc, it floated in front of me in a pathetic manner and this often resulted in the enemy team taking control of it.

The Meh

Initially, I thought the artwork for the game looked like it was going to be my kind of thing. It has a sort of Borderlands-esque feel to it, right? Not so much. Actual in game graphics didn’t really do it for me. They just seemed lacking.

This game is very much an online game. However, I played for a good long while and only ever had matches with bots. the community is, for all intents and purposes, much like a cemetery. You don’t need other players to play, luckily. As I said, you can play with bots.

Verdict: Nay

While part of me feels this is a bit harsh for a free-to-play game, I just can’t bring myself to recommend it as it is now. Maybe once it hits it’s final release I will revisit it and give it another go. Until then, I think I’ll stick to real air hockey and I would advise all of you to do the same. As always, thanks for reading.

Depending on how long you've been gaming, you will either see this game as yet another future team sports game, or the first of its kind.  The genre had been done to death by the late 80's/early 90's, but this game has online multiplayer which sounded like fun.

Unfortunately, there is rarely anyone online. The most it's ever shown is one person online as it spent 3 minutes trying to connect a game unsucessfully. For all I know, that one person was just me. In short, MP is pretty much a no-go depending on which time zone you are in. I'm yet to find anyone else to play with.

This leaves you to play against the bots, which would be fine if you had any control over your own team. Unfortunately, you only control one player or  at least try to with the slow and clunky controls, but that doesn't matter as your team rarely pass to you anyway. You are left running around on your own as one hogs the disk while your goalie usually ends up as the highest scorer... for the other team.  Lots of own goals.

First rule of team sports games -  The player controls whoever has the ball" or at least has the ability to pass to and from bots. Otherwise its just BORING.

Without the inability to switch players on your team or even find anyone online

As a 1000+ hours vet(who doesn't play this anymore) I can tell you not to download this game. First of all the lag between servers is terrible - the best team in the world(which doesn't say much since there are around 20-25 actual players, no joke) keeps losing to a team comprised of new players when they play on the Europe server. If you're from NA I'll tell you that this game will be a very negative experience for you because out of those 20-25 players, at least 15 are from Europe, so you'll be playing on their server more often than not.

Also, you can't play this game outside of tournaments. The reason is that there aren't enough players, you will only play against bots. Again, unless you're from Europe, but even then you'll only have a specific 1-2 hours to play against real players. So if you don't like playing tournaments you won't be able to play this game.

Also, the game balance is embarrassing, and there are MANY bugs/head-scratching decisions made by devs. Don't expect the devs to make changes, because the main guy(btw, they have said on stream that they have two people working on ACE only) said on stream that they don't like listening to the community.

I will say the main reason for most people who stop playing this game(as they told me) was the community manager. In fact there's at least one other review complaining about the devs. You'll see why in less than a week after downloading this game. If you look at the steamcharts page for this game, you'll notice that they are losing players instead of gaining. It's not a coincidence.

To recap...The game in its current state is not worth your time, and the devs have made it clear they will not be improving it. And the ONLY way to play this game against real players is to participate in tournaments, which are organized by the community manager, which means it will be impossible for you to avoid him.

Do yourself a favor and don't download this game, even if you're from Europe.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am going to assume by the time you read this you have checked out some trailers of the game and you pretty much know what this game is about. In a nutshell the game is an intergalatic air hockey simulator in which you pick a Runner and try to score goals. You play against another team of up to 3 players. Matches last 5 minutes and if undecided run into sudden death, where a golden goal principe is enforced. I like the competive element of the game, it feels like a real sport.

First the bad: I tried the game a few months back and it was still very much an early access product. It lacked proper dedicated servers and the interface was cluncky at best. It also had quite a few serious bugs, like loading screens timing out or games starting and not being balanced properly (3v2 or 1v4). At the time I quit, but hey, the game was in early access and it didn't claim to be anything else.

Now the good: About two weeks back I logged back in and was pleasantly suprised: dedicated servers, loading bugs completely fixed and a new slick interface (that naturally could still use some work here and there). It has come to a point where I would definitely recommend the game. There are still some issues, for example some problems with quests registering multiple times, but the core game itself is solid, fun and very easy to get into. The worst problem at the moment though is the limited number of players. Personally I don't mind playing some bots every now and again, but when this happens a lot the game loses some of its tension, because it is great to face off against other players. Besides, the game is free, so why not give it a bash.

My final thoughts? With some more players this game would be great fun. It feels amazing to score that deciding goal a few seconds before the timer runs out, let alone win a match that has run into sudden death by a well timed shot or a great long pass. Do yourself a favor and check out Arena: Cyber Evolution, or ACE for short.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was initially impressed by the game but seeing how the developers make mistake after mistake by prioritizing cosmetics and new Runners over actual much-needed content (more game modes, more maps, etc.) I'm starting to feel dissappointed by the game. There is only one gamemode, on one map, there's no midgame/endgame etc. to have the game actually develop during a match. The in-game controls are far too simple and lacking for what is considered by the devs as an eSport game. Things such as curve-shots, shot-power regulation, team-passing etc. are missing making the gameplay very shallow gameplay. While this was originally promoted as a community-driven game, the developers have completely moved away from this concept; there is very little room for community input or willingness to engage in discussions which hints at sheer arrogance from the developers' side that they can simply build a competitive game without the input from the playerbase. While some of the developers have prior experience in the gaming industry, as a company Spearhead Games has almost no history of developing games therefore making it an even worse move to not include the community more in the development.

If I'd have to rate the game right now, I'd give it a 4/10, with the potential for a 8/10 or 9/10, though it's unlikely that the game is ever going to progress to this point.
